description: First attested from 1603, from Middle French enthousiasme, from Late Latin enthusiasmus, from Ancient Greek ἐνθουσιασμός (enthousiasmós), from ἐν (en, “in”) + θεός (theós, “god”) + οὐσία (ousía, “essence”).

entries.meaning: Intensity of feeling; excited interest or eagerness.
examples: They have a great enthusiasm for country music.

entries.meaning: Something in which one is keenly interested.
examples: My main enthusiasm is attending and seeing the progress and interest of collectors, to meet old friends, and hopefully to make new friends.

entries.meaning: (obsolete or historical) Possession by a god; divine inspiration or frenzy.
